title-group.article-title: Determinants of non-adherence to antiretroviral therapy among seropositive pregnant women at public health facilities in Dessie Town, Ethiopia, 2024

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Non-adherence to antiretroviral therapy (ART) among pregnant women poses significant challenges to effective Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) treatment outcomes and the promotion of maternal and infant health. This study identifies factors influencing ART non-adherence among HIV-positive pregnant women attending public health facilities in Dessie Town, Ethiopia.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: A facility-based case–control study was conducted with 278 participants across health institutions in Dessie Town, comprising 208 controls and 70 cases. Non-adherence to ART was assessed using the 8-item Morisky Medication Adherence Scale (MMAS-8. Data were collected through structured interviewer-administered questionnaires and by reviewing patients' medical records using pretested instruments. The collected data were coded and entered into EpiData version 4.6, then analyzed using SPSS version 25. Variables with a P-value of 0.2 in Bivariable analysis were included in a multivariable regression model, and Adjusted Odds Ratios (AOR) with 95% confidence intervals (CI) were calculated. P-values less than 0.05 were considered statistically significant.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: In total, 208 controls and 70 cases were included in the study. Significant factors determining non-adherence to ART among HIV-positive pregnant women included forgetfulness to take ART (AOR = 2.414, 95% CI = 1.067–5.464, P = 0.034), non-disclosure (AOR = 2.955, 95% CI = 1.431–6.103, P = 0.003), an unplanned pregnancy (AOR = 3.045, 95% CI = 1.439–6.445, P = 0.004), those who did not participate in mother-support groups (AOR = 3.278, 95% CI = 1.611–6.672, P = 0.001), World Health Organization (WHO) clinical stages III & IV (AOR = 2.669, 95% CI = 1.279–5.569, P = 0.009), and those who did not take opportunistic infection prophylaxis (AOR = 3.873, 95% CI = 1.549–9.688, P = 0.004).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Key determinants included forgetfulness, non-disclosure of HIV status, unplanned pregnancies, lack of participation in mother-support groups, advanced WHO clinical stages (III & IV), and non-use of opportunistic infection prophylaxis.

sec.title: Recommendations
sec.p: All relevant parties, including front-line healthcare professionals, should advise women to use family planning more frequently to reduce unintended pregnancies. They should also encourage health education regarding disclosing HIV status to her spouse and ensure that all pregnant women are provided with opportunistic infection prophylaxis.

custom-meta.meta-value: © BioMed Central Ltd., part of Springer Nature 2025

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: HIV remains a major global public health issue, having claimed an estimated 42.3 million lives to date. Approximately 39.9 million people were living with HIV at the end of 2023, 65% of whom are in the African Region [1]. However, the introduction of highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART) has significantly improved the longevity of individuals infected with the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) and has dramatically reduced the rate of mother-to-child transmission (MTCT) of the virus [2]. Since the advent of HAART, MTCT rates have plummeted to less than 2%. However, the effectiveness of HAART, like any medication, hinges on the intrinsic properties of the drugs and the individual's adherence to the prescribed regimen. Achieving viral suppression is essential to minimize the risk of transmitting HIV to the baby [3, 4]. Despite this effectiveness, non-adherence to HAART remains a barrier to achieving its maximum benefits, especially that of prevention of mother-to-child transmission of HIV [5].

Globally, adherence to ART among pregnant women varies widely, ranging from 35% to 93.5%, reflecting differences in healthcare access, social support, and adherence interventions across different settings [6]. In Africa, a study covering multiple regions found that 19.8% of women exhibited suboptimal ART adherence, with significant regional variations—18.0% in Eastern Africa and 32.8% in Western Africa [7]. In Ethiopia, a study reported that 83.2% of pregnant women had good adherence to ART for the prevention of mother-to-child transmission (PMTCT), indicating that 16.8% were non-adherent. The most commonly cited reasons for non-adherence in Ethiopia included forgetfulness (79%) and being busy (71%), emphasizing the need for targeted interventions such as adherence counseling and reminder systems to improve ART uptake among pregnant women [8].

According to the World Health Organization (WHO), adherence to antiretroviral therapy (ART) means the extent to which a person's behavior—taking medication, following a diet, and/or executing lifestyle changes—corresponds with agreed recommendations from a healthcare provider [9]. High levels of adherence are crucial for the effectiveness of ART, as they help maintain viral suppression, improve immune function, and reduce the risk of HIV transmission and drug resistance. The WHO emphasizes that adherence rates of at least 95% are necessary to achieve optimal outcomes. This means that patients must take their medication correctly and consistently, adhering to prescribed dosages and schedules, to ensure that the virus remains undetectable and the treatment remains effective [10–12].

According to recent global estimates by UNAIDS, 82% of pregnant women living with HIV were receiving antiretroviral therapy (ART) to prevent vertical transmission of HIV, resulting in an estimated 220,000 infants being born HIV-free. Despite these successes, an estimated 130,000 children under the age of 15 acquired HIV in 2022, highlighting the critical importance of ART adherence in preventing vertical transmission of HIV [13]. Non-adherence to antiretroviral therapy among pregnant women poses a significant challenge in managing HIV and ensuring maternal and infant health. ART is crucial for controlling viral loads and preventing the transmission of HIV from mother to child during pregnancy and childbirth. However, adherence can be particularly difficult for pregnant women due to several factors that lead to uncontrolled viral loads, increasing the risk of HIV transmission to the infant during pregnancy, labor, or breastfeeding [4, 14]. This elevated viral presence also heightens the likelihood of the mother experiencing complications such as opportunistic infections or progression to AIDS [4, 8].

Non-adherence poses serious risks to both maternal and fetal health, making it a critical public health concern. However, most existing research on ART adherence among pregnant women in Ethiopia has focused on major urban centers like Addis Ababa, [15, 16] with limited data available from Dessie Town and its surrounding areas. Given the regional disparities in healthcare access and socio-cultural beliefs, a location-specific analysis is essential to understand the unique barriers affecting adherence in this setting. Furthermore, there is a lack of research evaluating the impact of key health system interventions, such as participation in mother-support groups, which play a crucial role in improving adherence and providing psychosocial support. To address these gaps, this study aims to identify the determinants of ART non-adherence among pregnant women attending Prevention of Mother-to-Child Transmission (PMTCT) follow-up services in health facilities in Dessie Town, South Wollo, Ethiopia.

sec.title: Study setting, period, study design, and population
sec.p: A facility-based unmatched Case–control study was undertaken from August 2022 to August 2023 at Dessie town public health facilities, South Wollo, Ethiopia, which is located 401 km from Ethiopia's capital city, Addis Ababa. According to the town administrative health office report, the town had 10 urban and 6 rural kebeles with an estimated population of 218,471 people, with 102,378 (46.86%) males and 116,093 (53.14%) females. Women of reproductive age constituted 51,870 (23.7%) of the total population. There were five hospitals (two government and three private), eight health centers (three of which provided ART services), and twenty-seven private clinics. This study involved two hospitals (DCSH and Boru Meda) and three health centers (Hote, Segno Gebeya, and Buanbua Wuha) Health centers. The selection of health facilities for this study was based on service availability and patient load to ensure the reliability and relevance of the data. Priority was given to facilities that offer both ART services and maternal healthcare, as these are essential for addressing key public health concerns. Additionally, institutions with higher patient flow were preferred, as they provided a more diverse patient population and a larger dataset, enhancing the study's validity. Furthermore, since ART services are provided free of charge in government healthcare institutions, the majority of patients seek care in these settings. This approach ensured that the selected facilities were well-equipped to provide comprehensive insights into healthcare service delivery within the study area.

sec.title: Study population
sec.p: Cases: included pregnant women on ART who were non-adherent and accessible during data collection, while controls comprised adherent pregnant women on ART who were accessible throughout the data collection period. [17, 18].

sec.title: Criteria for eligibility
sec.p: All pregnant mothers with HIV who had been using ART for at least three months were included in this study. Patients who were seriously ill or who arrived to start ART during the data collection period were not included.

sec.title: Sampling technique and determination of sample size
sec.p:
The sample size for this research was determined using the double population proportion formula in Epi info version 7.1 program, with the assumptions of 95% confidence level, 80% power, and 1:3 case-to-control ratio. The sample size was determined for each independent variable that the chosen study identified as a major factor in statistics. The first two variables (occupation and treatment supporter) in the table below were obtained from a study conducted in Nigeria [2]. The next two variables (age and monthly income) and the last variable (rural residence) were taken from the study done in southern and eastern Ethiopia respectively [3, 8]. The variable that has been found to yield a larger sample size was then employed. From the selected health facility in the study area, there were 265(68 cases and 198 controls) pregnant mothers on ART. After adding a 5% non-response rate the calculated sample size was 278(70 cases and 208 controls) (Table 1). Table 1
Sample size calculation for determinants of non-adherence to ART among HIV-positive pregnant mothers in public health facilities of Dessie town, South Wollo Zone, Ethiopia, 2023
Variables% Of controls exposedAOR% Of cases exposedSample size
Occupation/employed63.60.2236.4250
Treatment supporter30.30.0669.7265
Age (25–29)39.30.04379.5180
Monthly income (< 1000ETB)47.60.1852.4263
Rural residence40.90.1459.1260
AOR Adjusted odds ratio

A consecutive sampling procedure was used to select the cases, where all eligible participants who met the inclusion criteria were recruited sequentially until the required number of cases was achieved. For the selection of controls, a systematic sampling technique was applied, where controls were chosen at regular intervals from a predefined list of eligible individuals without the condition or exposure, ensuring a 1:3 case-to-control ratio.

sec.title: Dependent variable
sec.p: Non-adherence to ART (Yes/No).

sec.title: Independent variable
sec.p: Age of the Women, Marital status, economic status of the women, educational status, WHO clinical stage of the disease, Duration on ART, the time needed to reach the healthcare facility, Khat chewing, smoking, drinking alcohol, and Gestational age at ART initiation are some of the explanatory variables.

sec.title: Operational definitions
sec.p: Adherence is deemed acceptable when it reaches or surpasses 95%, signifying that fewer than 2 doses are overlooked out of 30 or fewer than 3 doses are skipped out of 60, according to records maintained by the healthcare provider overseeing Antiretroviral Therapy (ART).

non-adherence is characterized by percentages falling between 85 and 94%, indicating the omission of 3 to 5 doses out of 30 or 3 to 9 doses out of 60, as documented by the ART healthcare provider [12, 17–19].
Khat: a flowering plant having evergreen leaves that contains cathinone, a stimulant that causes excitement, loss of appetite, and euphoria.

Mother-support group: Mother-support group among HIV-positive women refers to a supportive and interactive communication platform where mothers living with HIV come together to share their experiences, insights, challenges, and successes related to their health, particularly in the context of managing HIV and adhering to Antiretroviral Therapy (ART).

sec.title: Data collection tools and measurements
sec.p: The overall data collection period spanned approximately three months, and the average time spent per patient was about 30 min. This included obtaining informed consent, administering a structured interview, reviewing the patient's medical records for relevant clinical data, and providing any necessary clarifications based on the participant’s responses.

A standardized questionnaire was used to interview the patients, gathering additional information on sociodemographic factors and patient-related aspects. Further details were obtained from the medical records after the patients'discharge, following their interview.

Non-adherence to ART was assessed using the 8-item Morisky Medication Adherence Scale (MMAS-8), a validated self-report tool that evaluates factors such as forgetfulness, carelessness, and stopping medication when feeling better. Participants scoring 0 were considered adherent, while scores of 1–8 indicated non-adherence. Following a thorough review of relevant literature [4, 8, 20], the questionnaires were revised to enhance their clarity and alignment with standardized terminology used in comparable studies. Several items were rephrased to ensure consistency in data collection and interpretation. Moreover, response scales were adjusted based on insights from previous research to increase the accuracy of responses, particularly for items assessing medication adherence and lifestyle-related behaviors.

One BSC midwife supervisor, three BSC midwives, and two diploma midwives were employed as data collectors. The percentage of doses the patient never missed during the previous 90 days was computed using a dose adherence method employed by the Ethiopian Federal Ministry of Health to evaluate adherence [12, 17].

sec.title: Data quality assurance
sec.p: To ensure consistency and accuracy, the questionnaire was first developed in English, then translated into Amharic, and back-translated into English to maintain linguistic and conceptual equivalence. Data collectors and supervisors participated in a one-day training session covering the study’s objectives, benefits, ethical considerations, informed consent procedures, and interview techniques.

The validity of the questionnaire was ensured through expert review and a pre-test. Subject matter experts assessed the content validity to confirm that the questionnaire adequately captured the study variables. A pretest was conducted on 14 participants at Kemise General Hospital before data collection, leading to necessary modifications to improve clarity and comprehension.
The reliability of the questionnaire was evaluated using Cronbach’s alpha to measure internal consistency. The overall Cronbach’s alpha value was 0.82, indicating good reliability.

sec.title: Data processing and analysis
sec.p: Data has been entered, classified coded, and outlined in epi data 4.6 on a computer before being transferred to SPSS version 25 for further analysis. The variance inflation factor (VIF < 7) and Tolerance (T > 0.1) were used to test for multicollinearity between independent variables. Hosmer–Lemeshow test was checked to evaluate model fitness (p = 0.791). The analysis was performed in three steps: first, descriptive analysis was performed to determine the frequency, percentage, means, and standard deviations of dependent and independent variables. Second, bivariate logistic regression was performed to see the association between explanatory and outcome variables. Third, variables that show association with a p-value of < = 0.2 on Bivariable analysis were fitted into a multivariable logistic regression model to see independently significant predictor variables by using Adjusted Odds Ratio (AOR) with a 95%confidence interval (CI). A p-value less than 0.05 will be taken as statistically significant.

sec.title: Ethical considerations
sec.p: Before the data collection procedure, Ethical approval has been obtained from Wollo University College of Medicine and Health Science ethical review committee with an ethical letter of CMHS/557/2015. Each respondent's name was withheld to protect their privacy. Those who agreed to take part in the study provided written and verbal consent after being informed. Everyone took part voluntarily, and the data was collected in accordance with the Helsinki Declaration.

sec.title: Sociodemographic characteristics of participants
sec.p:
A total of 278 pregnant women (70 cases and 208 controls) participated in the study, giving a response rate of 100%. Nearly 45.7% of the cases and 36.1% of the controls were below the age category of 25 years. The mean and standard deviation of the age of the cases and controls were 28 ± 9.8 and 29 ± 8.6 years, respectively. The majority of the cases and controls were married which were 82.9% and 87.5% respectively. Regarding the educational status, 32.9% of the cases had completed primary school and 25.5% of controls can read and write. More than half (57.7%) of controls were urban residents (Table 2). Table 2

sec.title: Clinical related factors
sec.p: One of the determinants that was identified in this study was clinical-related factors. Twenty-two (31.4%) of cases were developed OIs while 144(69.2%) of controls were not developed OIs previously. The majority of the participants (67.8%) of controls had viral load > 1000 copies/ml. Thirty-eight (54.3%) of cases and 93 (44.7%) of controls who took part in the study were found in the 2nd trimester of pregnancy (13–28 weeks) (Table 2).

sec.title: Health service and patient-related factors
sec.p:
About 28(40%) of cases and 156(75%) of controls disclose their HIV status to their intimate partner. While, forty-two (60%) of the cases did not disclose their status. The majority of cases, accounting for 61.4% (n = 43), and controls, comprising 86.1% (n = 179), adhered to their prescribed medication regimen by taking their pills promptly. Nearly half of the controls (51.9%) and 65.7% of the cases took more than one hour to reach the health facilities. More than half of the cases (68.6%) and 30.8% of the controls did not participate in a mother support group. The majority of controls, 170(81.7%) and 41(58.6%) of cases, had planned pregnancy (Table 3, 4 and 5). Table 3

sec.title: Behavioral factors
sec.p: Addictive substances are other determinants that affect ART adherence. One hundred ninety-six (94.2%) of controls and 61(87.1%) of cases were not khat chewers. Among cases, 4.3% were alcohol drinkers and many of the controls (96.6%) were not alcohol users. In a small number of controls, 1% and 3.7% of cases were smokers.

sec.title: Determinants of non-adherence to ART
sec.p: Multivariate logistic regression was used to identify independent factors contributing to ART non-adherence while controlling for other variables. For instance, mothers who forgot to take ARTs were 2.414 times more likely to discontinue ART (AOR = 2.414, 95% CI = 1.067–5.464, P = 0.034). In terms of WHO clinical stages, HIV-positive pregnant mothers on ART in clinical stages III and IV were 2.669 times more likely to be non-adherent compared to those in clinical stages I and II (AOR = 2.669, 95% CI = 1.279–5.569, P = 0.009).

Additionally, respondents who did not participate in the mother support group were 3.278 times more likely to be non-adherent than those who did (AOR = 3.278, 95% CI = 1.611–6.672, P = 0.004). We also found that respondents who did not take opportunistic infection prophylaxis were 3.87 times more likely to be non-adherent than those who took opportunistic infection prophylaxis [AOR (95%CI) = 2.378(1.549–9.688)].

Mothers who did not disclose their HIV status had 2.955 times the odds of non-adherence compared to mothers who disclosed their status (AOR = 2.955, 95% CI = 1.431–6.103, P = 0.003). Lastly, participants with unplanned pregnancies were 3.045 times more likely to be non-adherent compared to those with planned pregnancies (AOR = 3.045, 95% CI = 1.439–6.445, P = 0.004).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Poor outcomes of HIV treatment are still primarily due to non-adherence to ART [17]. A long-term commitment to adherence lowers the risk of developing opportunistic infections, prevents disease transmission, and helps to maintain adequate viral load suppression.

One of the key indicators significantly linked to ART non-adherence among HIV-positive pregnant women is the lack of participation in mother support groups. Women who did not join these groups were 3.3 times more likely to be non-adherent to ART compared to those who did participate. This difference may be due to the multifaceted benefits these groups provide. These support groups offer a sense of community and shared experience, reducing feelings of isolation and stigma that can be significant barriers to adherence. Through peer support, women receive encouragement, practical advice, and emotional backing, which enhances their motivation and commitment to maintaining their ART regimen. Additionally, mother support groups often provide education on the importance of ART adherence for both maternal health and the prevention of mother-to-child transmission of HIV, empowering women with knowledge and resources [3]. This outcome is consistent with research done in southern Uganda, Ghana, and South Africa where support groups similarly contribute to improved adherence. However, differences exist in their roles: Uganda integrates economic empowerment initiatives, Ghana emphasizes home visits and family involvement, and South Africa leverages digital health interventions and advocacy, while Ethiopia primarily relies on peer support within healthcare settings [21–23].

In terms of WHO clinical stages, pregnant women on ART who had clinical stages III & IV had a 2.7-fold higher chance of non-adherence than those who had clinical stages I & II. This result is in line with research from Ethiopia, Kenya, and Malawi [4, 24–26]. This may stem from the heightened severity and complexity of symptoms in advanced HIV stages. Patients often face physical and psychological challenges, such as opportunistic infections and neurological complications, which complicate adherence [27]. However, some studies have found conflicting results, suggesting that women with advanced disease may actually have higher adherence due to frequent medical follow-ups and closer monitoring of viral load [28]. These differences may be explained by variations in healthcare access and support systems across different regions in Ethiopia. Early diagnosis and timely initiation of ART could help prevent disease progression and improve adherence rates.
In contrast, patients in stages I and II often experience milder symptoms and have a better overall health status, making it easier for them to maintain a regular ART regimen [13].

Furthermore, respondents who forgot to take ART drugs were 2.4 times more likely to be non-adherent than their counterparts. This result is comparable to the study done in South Africa [6]. ART often requires a strict schedule for maximum effectiveness, and missing doses can compromise treatment outcomes and lead to drug resistance. When individuals forget to take their medication, they disrupt this critical schedule, which can result in suboptimal viral suppression and treatment failure. Unlike other factors such as stigma or side effects, which may be addressed through counseling or medical intervention, forgetfulness requires systematic solutions, such as reminders or pill organizers, to effectively manage adherence [29].

The current study also discovered that opportunistic infection prophylaxis was substantially related to non-adherence to ART in HIV-positive pregnant mothers. According to this study, participants who did not get opportunistic infection prophylaxis were 3.9 times more likely to non-adhere than those who did, which is corroborated by a study done in Addis Ababa [15]. This might be due to the fact that without prophylaxis, these women are at a higher risk of developing opportunistic infections, which can lead to frequent illness, hospitalization, and overall poor health. These complications can disrupt their daily routines, making it challenging to consistently take ART as prescribed. The physical and psychological burden of managing multiple health issues without the preventive benefits of prophylaxis can diminish their capacity and motivation to adhere to ART. Additionally, the absence of regular medical oversight that typically accompanies prophylaxis can result in a lack of continuous education and reinforcement about the importance of ART adherence, further contributing to non-adherence. In contrast, women who receive opportunistic infection prophylaxis are generally healthier, better supported, and more informed, which facilitates consistent ART adherence [9]. Chemoprophylaxis was advised in the Ethiopian national programs to prevent the incidence of opportunistic infections [14].

In this study, the determinant factor for ART non-adherence among HIV-positive pregnant mothers. The odds of being non-adherent among those mothers who did not disclose their HIV status to their parents or spouses were 2.9 times more likely to be non-adherent than those who disclosed their HIV status. This is in line with the study done in Tigray, northern Ethiopia, and Nigeria [25, 30]. When individuals do not inform their spouses about their HIV status, they often experience heightened stress and anxiety about the potential discovery, leading to a clandestine approach to taking medication. This secrecy can cause them to miss doses or take their medication inconsistently, fearing their partner's reaction if the medication is discovered. Notably, in Dessie Town, non-disclosure rates are higher than in other regions, possibly due to deep-rooted cultural stigmas, fear of marital dissolution, and lower awareness of HIV-related rights. Studies from Addis Ababa suggest higher disclosure rates, likely due to stronger community sensitization programs and greater access to psychosocial support services. Strengthening community-based stigma reduction programs and confidential disclosure counseling may help mitigate these challenges, particularly in urban centers like Dessie, where social stigma remains a significant barrier [16, 31]. Without open communication and support from their partner, the individual may struggle with feelings of isolation and the overwhelming responsibility of managing their treatment alone. In contrast, those who disclose their status to their partners can benefit from a supportive and cooperative relationship, where the partner can assist with reminders, provide emotional support, and create an environment that encourages consistent ART adherence [28]. According to WHO, pregnant women in Sub-Saharan Africa have the lowest rate of HIV disclosure globally [32]. Fear of disclosing one's HIV status to partners, family, or the community remains a major barrier to treatment adherence [20, 28].

The odds of being non-adherence among participants with unplanned pregnancies were 3.045 times more likely to be non-adherent than those with planned pregnancies. This is in line with the study done in Ukraine and South Africa [28, 33]. This disparity can be attributed to several factors. Unplanned pregnancies often come with increased stress, anxiety, and financial strain, which can significantly impact an individual’s ability to focus on and manage their healthcare needs effectively [30]. Additionally, the emotional and psychological adjustments required during an unplanned pregnancy may overshadow the importance of adhering to treatment plans, leading to higher rates of non-compliance. In contrast, individuals with planned pregnancies may have better support systems, more preparation, and a higher level of commitment to their health care, contributing to greater adherence rates [34, 35].

sec.title: Limitations of the study
sec.p: The study relied on self-reported data from participants, which can be subject to recall bias and social desirability bias that may affect the accuracy of the information on ART adherence.
There may be a selection bias as the study participants were those who attended the health facilities, potentially excluding women who did not seek care or were lost to follow-up.
Since the study focuses on women attending ART follow-up, the results may not be generalizable to all pregnant women.

sec.title: Conclusion and recommendation
sec.p: This study identified several factors contributing to non-adherence to antiretroviral therapy (ART) among HIV-positive pregnant women. These factors include opportunistic infections, advanced WHO clinical stages III and IV, non-enrollment in mother support groups, non-disclosure of HIV status, unintended pregnancies, failure to take opportunistic infection prophylaxis, and forgetfulness. These determinants highlight the complex interplay of medical, social, and psychological challenges that impede adherence to ART, ultimately jeopardizing the health of both mothers and their infants and increasing the risk of mother-to-child transmission of HIV.

sec.title: Recommendations
sec.p: Increase the availability and accessibility of mother support groups to offer emotional, informational, and practical support to HIV-positive pregnant women, thereby encouraging adherence to ART.
Develop supportive environments and counseling services that promote the safe disclosure of HIV status, reduce stigma, and improve adherence to ART.
Provide comprehensive reproductive health services, including family planning and counseling, to prevent unintended pregnancies and mitigate their impact on ART adherence.
Ensure that all HIV-positive pregnant women receive and adhere to prophylactic treatments for opportunistic infections.
Implement reminder systems, such as mobile health technologies, pill organizers, and regular follow-up visits, to help women remember to take their medication.

def.p: Prevention of Mother to Child Transmission

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: We would like to thank all ART clients who provided their consent and participated in this study. We express our appreciation to the data collectors, Wollo University, and health facility managers, who assisted us in the accomplishment of this study.

notes.title: Authors’ contributions
notes.p: All authors made a significant contribution to the work reported, whether that is in the conception, study design, execution, acquisition of data, analysis, and interpretation, or in all these areas; took part in drafting, revising, or critically reviewing the article; gave final approval of the version to be published; have agreed on the journal to which the article has been submitted; and agree to be accountable for all aspects of the work.

notes.p: No datasets were generated or analysed during the current study.
